sub_category_code: W.P. et al. (2016). NDC Explorer. German Development Institute / Deutsches Institut für Entwicklungspolitik (DIE)
title: Stockholm Environment Institute (SEI). DOI: 10.23661/ndc_explorer_2017_2.0
Type of targets
description: This sub-category shows the type or types of target of each INDC submitted
classification-4: Peaking target

title: Limiting global temperature increase
description: This sub-category shows whether countries refer to limiting the global temperature increase (above pre-industrial levels) as negotiated under the UNFCCC. The subcategory also shows which (I)NDCs claim to be consistent with limiting the global temperature increase to 2°C or 1.5 °C above pre-industrial levels
classification-1: Not mentioning global effort to limit global temperature increase to 2°C or 1.5°C
classification-2: Mentioning global effort to limit global temperature increase to 2°C
classification-3: Mentioning global effort to limit global temperature increase to 1.5°C
classification-4: (I)NDC claims to be consistent with 2°C limit
classification-5: (I)NDC claims to be consistent with 1.5°C limit

title: Costs of mitigation/investment needs
description: (partial) Costs of reaching the mitigation contribution as described in parties’ INDCs (in US$). Some countries provide full costs estimates, others provide costs of individual projects
classification-4: 5-10 billion US$ until 2030

title: Mitigation focus areas: renewable energy
description: Consideration of and prioritization/highlighting of renewable energy (RE) to reach mitigation ambitions. When indicated in (I)NDCs, quantified renewable energy targets and specific sub-sectors of action (e.g. solar, geothermal, wind power) are also indicated for individual countries

title: Mitigation focus areas: energy efficiency
description: Consideration of and prioritization/highlighting of energy efficiency (EE) to reach mitigation ambitions. When indicated in (I)NDCs, quantified renewable energy targets and specific sub-sectors of action (e.g. solar, geothermal, wind power) are also indicated for individual countries

title: Mitigation focus areas: transport
description: Consideration of and prioritization/highlighting of the transport sector to reach the mitigation ambitions. When indicated in (I)NDCs, specific transport sectors are also indicated for individual countries

title: Mitigation focus areas: carbon capture and Storage (CCS)
description: Consideration of and prioritization/highlighting of carbon capture and storage (CCS) to reach the mitigation ambitions

title: Mitigation focus areas: agriculture
description: Consideration of and prioritization/highlighting of agriculture  to reach the mitigation ambitions

title: Mitigation focus areas: land use and forestry
description: Reference to land use and forestry in (I)NDCs; and whether emissions from land use and forestry and mitigation potential of the land use and forestry are quantified

title: Mitigation focus areas: waste
description: Consideration of and prioritization/highlighting of the waste sector to reach the mitigation ambitions

title: Reducing non-CO2 gases
description: The sub-category indicates whether countries considered the reduction of non-CO2 gases in order to reach the mitigation ambitions. When indicated in (I)NDCs, considered gases are also indicated for individual countries

title: Fossil fuel subsidiaries
description: Explicit consideration of and prioritization/highlighting of replacing fossil fuels with alternatives (subsidiaries) to reach the mitigation ambitions

title: Land use change
description: Consideration of and prioritization/highlighting of land use change to reach the mitigation ambitions
classification-4: quantified, no mitigation target

title: REDD+
description: Explicit reference to the term “Reducing Emissions of Deforestation and Forest Degradation” and/or the acronym REDD/REDD+. Party-specific information is indicated when available

title: Trade
description: Reference to international trade and/or trade measures and whether they are used as an instrument to foster mitigation (please note: issues such as fossil fuel subsidy reform and carbon trade are coded in other subcategories)
classification-3: International trade/trade measures to foster mitigation

title: Market mechanisms
description: Market mechanisms make greenhouse gas emissions a tradable commodity. This subcategory  indicates parties' interest in using market mechanisms to implement the (I)NDC
classification-4: Market mechanisms to meet conditional contribution only
classification-5: Use of market mechanisms to meet part of (I)NDC target

title: Supplementary mitigation plans and strategies
description: References in (I)NDCs to other mitigation plans and strategies, either domestic or in the context of the UNFCCC
classification-2: Reference to UNFCCC-related plans and strategies
classification-3: Reference to domestic plans and strategies
classification-4: Reference to both UNFCCC- and domestic plans and strategies

title: Co-benefits of mitigation
description: Consideration and description of co-benefits of mitigation. Parties’ specific examples are included
classification-4: Both adaptation and other co-benefits

title: Migration and displacement
description: Reference to migration/displacement as a consequence of climate impacts and/or relocation as adaptation strategy. Party-specific information is indicated
classification-2: Risk of displacement/migration as a consequence of climate change
classification-4: displacement/migration both mentioned as climate change consequence and adaptation strategy

title: Vulnerability: agriculture
description: Agriculture is among the five sectors most often described as vulnerable

title: Vulnerability: water
description: Water is among the five sectors most often described as vulnerable

title: Vulnerability: ecosystems
description: Ecosystems are among the five sectors most often described as vulnerable

title: Vulnerability: health
description: Health is among the five sectors most often described as vulnerable

title: Vulnerability: coastal zones
description: Coastal zones are among the five 5 sectors most often described as vulnerable

title: Costs of recent climate-related hazards (currency US$)
description: Describes monetary and non-monetary costs countries suffered from recent climate-related hazards, such as floods, storms and droughts. Specific impacts, year and events are illustrated if available
classification-4: Human impacts and economic loss mentioned

title: Costs of future climate-related hazards (currency US$)
description: Describes expected monetary and non-monetary costs from climate-related hazards, such as floods, storms and droughts. Specific impacts and events are illustrated if available

title: Climate risks: extreme weather
description: Extreme weather events is among the five climate risks that are described most often as concerns. Parties’ specific examples of extreme events are also indicated
classification-2: Extreme weather mentioned as climate risk

title: Climate risks: floods
description: Floods are among the five climate risks most often described as concerns

title: Climate risks: droughts
description: Droughts are among the five climate risks most often described as concerns

title: Climate risks: temperature increase
description: Temperature increase is among the climate risks most often described as concerns
classification-2: temperature increase mentioned as climate risk

title: Climate risks: sea level rise
description: Sea level rise is among the five climate risks most often described as concerns
classification-1: Sea level rise not included/not applicable
classification-2: Sea level rise mentioned as climate risk

title: Priority sectors: water
description: Water is among the five sectors most often described in the context of adaptation ambitions. ‘Elaborated upon’ signifies that an (I)NDC describes specific actions or aims

title: Priority sectors: agriculture
description: Agriculture is among the five sectors most often described in the context of adaptation ambitions. ‘Elaborated upon’ signifies that an (I)NDC describes specific actions or aims

title: Priority sectors: health
description: Health is among the five sectors most often described in the context of adaptation ambitions. ‘Elaborated upon’ signifies that an (I)NDC describes specific actions or aims

title: Priority sectors: biodiversity/ecosystems
description: Biodiversity/ecosystems is among the five sectors most often described in the context of adaptation ambitions. ‘Elaborated upon’ signifies that an (I)NDC describes specific actions or aims

title: Priority sectors: forestry
description: Forestry is among the five sectors most often described in the context of adaptation ambitions. ‘Elaborated upon’ signifies that an (I)NDC describes specific actions or aims

title: Quantified adaptation targets
description: Highlight which countries included quantified targets in their INDCs, and shows the sectors for which (I)NDCs include quantitative targets
classification-4: Targets in more than 3 sectors

title: Costs of adaptation/investment needs
description: (partial) Costs of reaching the adaptation contribution as described in parties’ INDCs (in US$). Some countries provide full cost estimates, others provide costs of individual projects
classification-4: 5-10 billion US$ until 2030

title: Supplementary adaptation plans and strategies
description: Reference to other adaptation plans and strategies, either domestic or in the context of the UNFCCC (e.g. National Adaptation Programme of Action (NAPA) or National Adaptation Plan (NAP))
classification-2: Reference to UNFCCC-related plans and strategies
classification-3: Reference to domestic plans and strategies
classification-4: Reference to both UNFCCC- and domestic plans and strategies

title: Co-benefits of adaptation
description: Consideration and description of co-benefits of adaptation. Parties’ specific examples are included.
classification-4: Both mitigation and other co-benefits

title: Conditionality of adaptation finance
description: Mentioning of adaptation finance/support, and whether countries make such international finance conditional for the adaptation contribution in their (I)NDC
classification-3: adaptation finance partly conditional to contribution
classification-4: adaptation finance fully conditional to contribution

title: Conditionality of mitigation finance
description: Mentioning of mitigation finance/support, and whether countries make such international finance conditional for the adaptation contribution in their (I)NDC
classification-3: mitigation finance partly conditional to contribution
classification-4: mitigation finance fully conditional to contribution

title: Technology needs
description: Mentioning of technologies, and whether (I)NDCs mention specific technologies (mitigation and/or adaptation)

title: Conditionality of technology transfer
description: Mentioning of technology transfer, and whether the implementation of (I)NDCs is (partly ) conditional technology transfer
classification-3: Technology transfer  (partly) conditional to INDC implementation

title: Conditionality of capacity building
description: Mentioning of capacity building and whether the implementation of (I)NDCs is (partly) conditional to capacity building
classification-3: Capacity building (partly) conditional to INDC implementation

title: Means of Implementation and fairness/equity
description: Indicates whether (I)NDCs refer to a need for Means of Implementation (MoI: capacity building, climate finance, technology transfer) in their dedicated fairness/equity section
classification-2: MoI not mentioned in fairness/equity section
classification-4: MoI specified in fairness/equity section

title: Climate risk insurance
description: Indicates whether (I)NDCs refer to existing risk insurance mechanisms or plan to develop risk insurance mechanisms to deal with climate change impacts
classification-4: Global/Regional insurance facility

title: Planning of (I)NDC formulation
description: Mentioning of INDC formulation planning, as well as certain specific aspects (e.g. consultations, workshops, public awareness campaigns, inter-governmental coordination, highest political level approval, etc.)

title: (I)NDC preparation: stakeholder consultation
description: Mentioning of stakeholder consultation processes in the formulation of (I)NDC, as well as the involvement of specific actors (government institutions, private sector, academia, international experts, etc.)

title: Education
description: Mentioning of education, and whether countries plan to do education to implement their INDC (adaptation, mitigation or both)
classification-3: Education to implement (I)NDC, aim not clear
classification-4: Education to implement the (I)NDC’s adaptation contribution
classification-5: Education to implement the (I)NDC’s mitigation contribution
classification-6: Education to implementat the (I)NDC’s adaptation and mitigation contribution

title: Awareness raising
description: Mentioning of awareness raising on climate change, and whether countries plan to raise people's awareness to implement their INDC (adaptation, mitigation or both)
classification-3: Awareness raising to implement (I)NDC, aim not clear
classification-4: Awareness raising to implement the (I)NDC’s adaptation contribution
classification-5: Awareness raising to implement the (I)NDC’s mitigation contribution
classification-6: Awareness raising to implement the (I)NDC’s adaptation and mitigation contributions

title: Training
description: Mentioning of training on climate change, and whether countries plan to do training to implement their INDC (adaptation, mitigation or both)
classification-3: Training to implement (I)NDC, aim not clear
classification-4: Training to implement the (I)NDC’s adaptation contribution
classification-5: Training to implement the (I)NDC’s mitigation contribution
classification-6: Training to implement the (I)NDC’s adaptation and mitigation contributions

title: Access to information
description: Mentioning of access to information, and whether countries plan to improve information access to implement their INDC (adaptation, mitigation or both)
classification-3: Information access to implement (I)NDC, aim not clear
classification-4: Information access to implement the (I)NDC’s adaptation contribution
classification-5: Information access to implement the (I)NDC’s mitigation contribution
classification-6: Information access to implement the (I)NDC’s adaptation and mitigation contributions

title: Planning of (I)NDC implementation
description: Mentioning of INDC implementation, and whether parties aim to create specific laws and policies for the implementation
classification-3: Mentioned and creation of specific laws/policies

title: Monitoring and review
description: Indicates whether countries refer to assessment or review of INDCs, and whether they intend to track the implementation of their INDCs
classification-1: No reference to assessment or review
classification-2: Section on domestic monitoring and/or evaluation
classification-4: Section on domestic processes and reference to international review processes

title: Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)
description: The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) of the Agenda 2030 for Sustainable Development were decided upon by the UN General Assembly in 2015. This sub-category indicates whether SDGs were mentioned in the (I)NDCs and whether mainstreaming of SDG and (I)NDC implementation is planned
classification-4: Aim to mainstream INDC contribution and SDG implementation

title: Sustainable Development
description: Sustainable development is socially inclusive and environmentally sustainable economic growth. The concept was a cornerstone of the 1989 Brundtland report as well as three global UN conferences (1992 UNCED; 2002 WSSD; 2012 UNCSD). This category indicates whether (I)NDCs mention sustainable development

title: Fossil fuel subsidy reform
description: Indicates countries’ commitment in INDCs to change or phase out state subsidies of fossil fuels.

title: Green growth/green economy
description: ‘Green growth’ is a relatively new concept that describes low-emission and resource efficient economic growth. Ultimately, green growth should lead to green economies
classification-4: Green growth/economy strategy to be developed

title: Disaster Risk Reduction
description: Reference to disaster risk management/reduction and/or the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction
classification-4: Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction mentioned

title: Section on fairness/equity
description: Parties were asked to include information on how their INDC is fair and ambitious (Decision 1/CP.20, §14). This subcategory shows whether (I)NDCs dedicated a section to fairness or equity and whether they contextualize their emissions here
classification-2: Section included without contextualizing own emissions

title: Historical responsibility
description: The thought behind ‘historical responsibility’ is that countries with high emissions in the past (historical emissions) have a larger responsibility to address climate change than countries with low historical emissions.
classification-4: Quantified own historical responsibility

title: Loss and Damage
description: Loss and Damage (L&D) denotes climate change impacts that occur despite mitigation and adaptation efforts. This subcategory shows whether L&D is mentioned in INDCs, and whether this is done so in the context of finance needs.
classification-3: L&D mentioned in context of financial support

title: Gender
description: Mentioning of gender aspects and inclusion in a specific context (fairness and equity /adaptation/ capacity building)

title: Human rights
description: Mentioning of human rights aspects and inclusion in a specific context (fairness and equity, adaptation, capacity building)

title: Global division by income
description: Global division of countries in four income-level groups based on the World Bank Country Groups

title: Global division by region
description: Global division of countries in seven regional groups based on the World Bank Country Groups
classification-4: North America

title: G20 Legend Title
description: The G20 (or Group of Twenty) is an international forum for the governments and central bank governors from 20 major economies, founded in 1999
